September 2018

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The regional knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will prepare development 
master plans and enhance capacity development for the energy sector’s regional cooperation and 
integration (RCI) under the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) program. It 
will cover Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Myanmar, Nepal, and Sri Lanka.     
 
2.  The TA will support the implementation of the SASEC Operational Plan, 2016‒2025, which 
SASEC member countries endorsed in 2016.1 In 2017, SASEC finance ministers endorsed the 
SASEC Vision—the overarching framework and long-term strategy to support partnership among 
member countries—at a meeting in Delhi.2 SASEC officials agreed upon the flagship initiatives in 
the SASEC Vision at a subsequent meeting in Yokohama. The initiatives highlighted energy 
security and connectivity across the SASEC subregion to enhance cross-border power trade and 
improve  regional gas  supply  value  chains.3 To  promote these  activities,  SASEC  members 
accepted the need for TA when the Asian Development Bank (ADB) presented the concept at the 
SASEC nodal official meeting in Singapore in March 2018.4  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  To support RCI in the energy sector under SASEC, ADB has financed a series of regional 
TA programs, including recent studies that indicated significant regional benefits of cross-border 
power trade among the countries of SASEC and the South Asian Association for Regional 
Cooperation (SAARC).5 Cross-border power trading opportunities have rapidly expanded and 
been realized through physical transmission interconnections among some SASEC countries. 
The national electricity grids of Bangladesh and India, for example, were interconnected in 2013. 
While interconnections between India and Nepal were once limited to the border areas, a high-
capacity  grid  interconnection  was  commissioned  in  2016.  Bhutan  and  India  have  been 
constructing another high-voltage transmission link to evacuate about 3,000 megawatts from 
hydropower projects in Bhutan. Thus, these four countries have been physically and technically 
linked through India’s national grid, and additional interconnection and power trading opportunities 
are being discussed. ADB has financed some of the RCI projects, such as (i) the grid connections 
between Bangladesh and India and between Bhutan and India, (ii) some hydropower exports from 
Bhutan to India, and (iii) grid strengthening within Nepal for power import and export. Recently, 
India also started exporting power to Myanmar. In addition, India and Sri Lanka have been working 
closely on a feasibility study for a cross-border transmission link.   
 
4.  SASEC members comprise one of the fastest growing subregions with huge potential to 
expand cross-border power trading further. Indigenous energy resources, including coal, gas, 
hydropower, and other renewable energy sources, represent major opportunities for regional 
development. These different resources have complementarities for optimal utilization in the 
effective energy mix across the different countries and seasons.6 Despite the potential for more 
                                                
1  ADB. 2016. South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Operational Plan, 2016‒2025. Manila.  
2  ADB. 2017. SASEC: Powering Asia in the 21st Century. Manila. 
3  The three focuses in the energy sector are (i) cross-border power trade, (ii) gas storage terminals, and (iii) gas 
pipeline connectivity.  
4  The TA concept paper was approved on 25 April 2018. 
5  ADB. 2014. Technical Assistance for South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Cross-Border Power Trade 
Development. Manila. This TA was closed in 2017. The TA estimated investment benefits of more than $2,000 million 
through  cross-border  transmission  interconnections  among  Afghanistan,  Bangladesh,  Bhutan,  India,  Nepal, 
Pakistan, Sri Lanka, and Tajikistan.    
6  Each country has contrasting energy demand and supply patterns. For example, India and Bangladesh have their 
peak power demand in the summer, while Bhutan and Nepal have the peak in the winter.

2 
power trade, power flows are constrained by physical and nonphysical issues, including (i) limited 
transmission connection points and capacity, (ii) uncoordinated development plans of generation 
projects, (iii) complicated offtake and commercial contractual arrangements for power trade, 
(iv) inadequate regulatory and policy platforms and coordination mechanisms, (v) weak benefit 
assessments and risk-mitigation arrangements, and (vi) insubstantial financing instruments for 
capital-intensive investments. As an emerging need, SASEC members are paying more attention 
to renewable energy because of the growing focus on climate change. However, the subregion 
has not realized its renewable energy potential. The weather-dependent and unstable nature of 
the output, which has led to operational control difficulties in the grid systems, has become a 
technical concern for the grid operators. This opens up an opportunity for a regional strategy to 
address how to stabilize the power flows using backup hydropower from countries such as Bhutan 
and Nepal and/or any advanced battery systems for renewable energy expansion. 
 
5.  In addition to the intra-regional optimization of different energy resources, SASEC needs 
to focus on wider regional connectivity and more efficient energy transshipment in order to 
respond to its increasing dependence on energy imports from outside the subregion. For example, 
in response to the depletion of its domestic gas reserves, Bangladesh plans to import more power 
and liquefied natural gas (LNG). To meet the growing domestic demand for fuels, India is also 
expected to import more LNG, which is considered cleaner than coal and diesel. Maldives and 
Sri Lanka are also considering importing LNG for power generation and other uses. All SASEC 
countries have largely depended on the importation of other fuels, including liquified petroleum 
gas (LPG). In many cases, these resources are shipped from the Middle East or Singapore by 
small vessels because of constraints such as shallow water ports, insufficient storage facilities, 
and sparse pipeline networks. This has led to inflated import costs. The supply chain for LNG and 
LPG can be improved through regional shipping or terminal arrangements with more efficient 
networks of inland and coastal transport corridors of SASEC countries along the Bay of Bengal.7  
 
6.  Regional energy cooperation on power and gas supplies will benefit from lowering the 
energy costs of individual countries, improving energy security, and contributing to climate change 
mitigation. For these purposes, ADB and the SASEC countries agreed on the SASEC Operational 
Plan,  2016‒2025.  The  plan  indicated  possible  investment  project  pipelines  and  energy 
operational priorities to (i) improve interconnections in order to access large electricity and natural 
gas sources; (ii) harness unused regional indigenous hydropower potential; (iii) develop low-
carbon alternatives including solar and wind; and (iv) facilitate bilateral and regional coordination 
mechanisms and knowledge sharing, such as technology transfer development practices toward 
a regional power trading market. The SASEC Vision subsequently highlighted regional power and 
gas cooperation as the flagship initiatives. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  Past ADB assistance programs have focused on region-wide planning and modeling 
analysis to assess and advocate RCI in the energy sector, and some actions on physical 
connectivity have been initiated between some countries. To promote this development thrust, 
the TA will focus on more specific investment projects identified in the SASEC Operational Plan, 
2016‒2025; take problem-solving approaches on common issues related to the past and ongoing 
projects and proposals; and apply lessons from them to future investment projects. 
                                                
7  One possible approach is to bring large vessels from the Middle East or Singapore to some regional hub terminals, 
and then break the bulk fuels to be shipped or transported to many consumption points.

3 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: Investment in cross-border energy trade and 
cooperation increased. This will be supported through (i) improved interconnections of electricity 
and gas supply networks; (ii) exploited renewable energy potential including hydropower, solar, 
and wind; and (iii) enhanced coordination and knowledge sharing among SASEC countries. The 
TA will have the following outcome: cross-border projects and/or programs ready for investment 
support prioritized. This outcome can be realized through the TA outputs.8  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  The TA will focus on the power and gas subsectors, and their capacity development 
activities.  
 
10.  Output 1: Development master plans for cross-border power trade prepared. Using 
international best practices and case studies on the SASEC Operational Plan’s project priorities 
and pipelines, the TA will develop a master plan—including regional development strategies, road 
maps,  and  project  inventories—based  on  multi-criteria  analysis.  This  will  be  done  through 
assessments of project pre-feasibility studies, investment cost estimates, development options, 
technical  requirements,  regulatory  frameworks,  commercial  and  institutional  arrangements, 
climate change impacts, and any other focus areas.9 In 2017, SASEC established the Cross-
Border Power Trade Working Group, comprising mainly each government’s power or energy 
ministry, planning agency, and/or transmission and generation utilities. The working group will 
promote effective power trading arrangements and project assessments.10 The development of 
cross-border regulatory frameworks will also be coordinated with the SAARC Council of Experts 
of Energy Regulators (Electricity), which was established in line with the 2014 SAARC Framework 
Agreement for Energy Cooperation (Electricity).11    
 
11.  Output 2: Development master plans for regional gas cooperation prepared. As with 
the cross-border power trade, the TA will develop a master plan for the gas business. The plan 
will include regional development strategies and road maps, and project inventories based on 
multi-criteria analysis through assessments of project pre-feasibility studies, investment cost 
estimates, development options, technical requirements, regulatory frameworks, commercial and 
institutional arrangements, climate change impacts, and any other focus areas. In 2017, ADB 
discussed the concept of LNG and LPG transshipment with relevant countries based on the 
SASEC Vision’s initiatives. This will be extended to more strategic approaches for the SASEC 
subregion. Through market assessments of potential regional hubs across the SASEC subregion, 
their feasibility assessments and strategic investment plans will be prepared in coordination with 
a working group to be organized. To create more enabling investment environment, the TA will 
also harmonize regulatory rules and standards and safety management among the countries.   
 
12.  Output 3: Knowledge on advanced energy technologies increased. To make the 
above outputs and their activities practical, the TA will include knowledge sharing and capacity 
development on advanced technological applications and other regions’ RCI programs and 
                                                
8  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
9  In case any feasibility studies were already done, further assessments can be considered to clarify any other due 
diligence aspects and strengthen the results when appropriate.      
10 In 2017, SASEC’s first meeting on cross-border power trade finalized further study and capacity enhanced areas, 
including (i) economic and financial feasibility and institutional studies for some potential cross-border transmission 
projects; (ii) offtake, transmission services, and commercial options of hydropower projects; (iii) possible expansion 
of transmission connectivity to Myanmar; and (iv) knowledge and experience sharing on energy efficiency and 
renewable energy integration, the power exchange market, and smart grid elements.   
11 ADB supported the council’s meetings in 2016 and 2017, and the council identified a gap analysis in relevant laws 
and regulations and strategic road map assessments.

4 
activities. Advanced technologies can include efficient operations of LNG and LPG terminals and 
storage facilities, as well as renewable energy and its battery substation facilities.12 To incorporate 
lessons from other regional programs, the TA will update progress and issues of the Greater 
Mekong Subregion, the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation, and/or any other RCI 
programs. Relevant knowledge sharing seminars and site visits will also be conducted.  
 
13.  If projects and/or investments are identified as feasible, ADB will consider providing 
additional support to make them happen through further financial due diligence and structuring in 
consultation with relevant countries. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000, of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6) and (ii) $1,500,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) and administered by ADB. The 
key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
15.  ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund will mainly support the knowledge sharing and 
capacity development activities under output 3, including a project site visit to enable a delegation 
from SASEC member countries to learn about advanced technologies.13 JFPR will support 
activities related to outputs 1 and 2.14  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 3 years in coordination with the respective energy sector 
agencies in SASEC countries. ADB will be the executing agency and will carry out the TA in 
accordance with ADB’s rules and procedures.15 
 
17.   The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  September 2018–August 2021 
Executing agency  ADB 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
Individual consultants  International expertise  $1,360,000 
selection  (45 person-months) 
Disbursement  Resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
ADB = Asian Development Bank. 
Source: ADB. 
                                                
12  Emerging technologies and their impacts will be assessed in preparing the master plans. 
13  The delegation is expected to include each SASEC country’s working group member from the power and gas 
subsectors. On the site visit, they are expected to see advanced technological operations in Japan (e.g., LNG or 
LPG terminals, storage facilities, and renewable and its battery substation facilities).  
14 JFPR will finance the costs of consultants and participants in regional workshops, which are expected by 2020. 
JFPR’s policy guidelines for TA grants generally define (i) the following eligible expenditures: consultant services; 
non-consultant costs for local training and workshops; minimal equipment such as computers; and operating costs 
essential to carry out the TA, including vehicle rental, if justified, and knowledge partnership; and (ii) the following 
ineligible expenditures: purchase of vehicles, salaries for civil servants, foreign travel, scholarships or long 
internships, detailed engineering design, civil works, and other related expenses, and those under ADB’s List of 
Ineligible Items (or Negative List) and Prohibited Investment Activities List. 
15  ADB’s South Asia Department will collaborate in consultation with other regional departments when required.

5 
18.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.16 The consultants will coordinate the TA implementation with ADB and 
the  working  groups  from  the  SASEC  member  countries  in  the  discussion,  consultation, 
information-sharing and decision-making processes.17  
 
19.  Cofinancier requirements. The TA’s monitoring and reporting requirements and change 
in implementation arrangements will follow the JFPR guidelines.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $1,500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction, and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a 
grant basis for South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Regional Energy Cooperation, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.  
                                                
16  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
17  The SAARC Council of Experts of Energy Regulators (Electricity) will also be coordinated and supported in regulatory 
terms when appropriate. The activities involving SAARC will be undertaken through the SAARC Secretariat in Nepal.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.   Development master plan for cross-border power trade prepared. 
1.1  Engage consultants (Q3 2018). 
1.2  Submit study plans to set up multiple criteria for project analyses (Q3 2018).  
1.3  Organize the cross-border power trade working group discussion meetings (Q4 2018, Q2 2019, Q1 
2020, Q1 2021).c 
1.4  Submit draft report on (i) due diligence investment studies of flagship projects, (ii) development 
strategies and road maps, and (iii) knowledge-sharing business areas on international best practices 
(Q2 2019). 
1.5  Submit interim report on (i) due diligence investment studies of flagship projects; (ii) development 
strategies and road maps; and (iii) knowledge-sharing business areas on international best practices, 
with concrete institutional, commercial, and financing modalities (Q4 2019). 
1.6  Submit final report on (i) due diligence investment studies of flagship projects; (ii) development

with concrete institutional, commercial, and financing modalities (Q2 2020). 
1.7  Finalize the development master plan for cross-border power trade (Q2 2020).  
1.8  Support the working group in reviewing at least one flagship project for financing purposes (Q4 
2020). 
1.9  Submit the final review report on the flagship project preparation and financial closure (Q2 2021). 
2.   Development master plan for regional gas cooperation prepared. 
2.1  Engage consultants (Q3 2018). 
2.2  Submit study plans to set up multiple criteria for project analyses and knowledge sharing (Q3 2018).  
2.3  Organize the regional gas cooperation working group discussion meetings (Q4 2018, Q2 2019, Q1 
2020, Q1 2021). 
2.4  Submit draft report on (i) due diligence investment studies of flagship projects, (ii) development 
strategies and road maps, and (iii) knowledge-sharing business areas on international best practices 
(Q2 2019). 
2.5  Submit interim report on (i) due diligence investment studies of flagship projects; (ii) development 
strategies and road maps; and (iii) knowledge-sharing business areas on international best practices,

2.6  Submit final report on (i) due diligence investment studies of flagship projects; (ii) development 
strategies and road maps; and (iii) knowledge-sharing business areas on international best practices, 
with concrete institutional and financing modalities (Q2 2020). 
2.7  Finalize the development master plan for regional gas cooperation (Q2 2020).  
2.8  Support the working group in reviewing at least one flagship project for financing purposes (Q4 
2020). 
2.9  Submit the final review report on the flagship project preparation and financial closure (Q2 2021). 
3.   Knowledge on advanced energy technologies increased. 
3.1  Propose knowledge-sharing activities based on the international best practices of RCI in the energy 
sector (Q4 2018).  
3.2  Submit advanced technological options for regional knowledge-sharing in the power and gas 
subsectors (Q2 2019).  
3.3  Update and incorporate progress of other regional energy cooperation activities of GMS and 
CAREC, and proposed any joint activities with them (Q4 2018, Q2 2019, Q1 2020, Q1 2021). 
3.4  Organize a project site visit to see advance technology (Q4 2019).d

Assumptions for Partner Financing 
Not Applicable. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, CAREC = Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation, GMS = Greater Mekong 
Subregion, LNG = liquefied natural gas, LPG = liquified petroleum gas, Q = quarter, RCI = regional cooperation and 
integration, SASEC = South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation.  
a  Defined by this project. For this purpose, ADB and the SASEC countries agreed with the SASEC Operational Plan, 
2016‒2025, which indicated possible investment project pipelines and energy operational priorities to (i) improve 
interconnections to access large-scale electricity and natural gas sources, (ii) harness unused regional indigenous 
hydropower potential, (iii) develop low-carbon alternatives including solar and wind, and (iv) facilitate bilateral and 
regional coordination mechanisms and knowledge sharing such as technology transfer development practices 
toward regional power trading market (ADB. 2016. South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Operational Plan, 
2016‒2025. Manila). 
b   Includes climate change impact assessments (with any associated geophysical hazards) when appropriate.  
c   The first cross-border power trade working group meeting was held in October 2017.  
d  The site visit is to study advanced technological operations in Japan (e.g., LNG and LPG terminals and storage 
facilities, and renewable and its battery substation facilities).   
Source: ADB.

territory or area.
